The thing is, way back in Mary’s day, hand washing wasn’t of great importance.   In fact, surgeons used to wonder why their patients ended up dead after surgical intervention, until somebody discovered that they should wash their hands before performing surgery.     But as a cook, I find it hard to believe that Mary never washed her hands, because even if you had no intention to do so, for myself, personally, I find I’m always washing my hands whether I’m handling meat, rinsing greens, washing dishes (I don’t have a dish washer), but once you’re in the kitchen there are numerous reasons to be washing your hands - even if you didn’t understand the hygienic necessity.

She was an easy target for authorities. So where are the carriers today? Why is it that when Mary was put onto that island the disease continued ?
Gosh, she was Mary Bennet from the 1995 version of Pride and Prejudice.

This wasnt rare. The only reason they quarantine her for life is because of her repeated offense and also prejudice toward Irish woman at the time. Many other carriers were allowed to live while Mary was still alive. The health board even stated that it was impossible to quarantine the entire carrier population (100 per year out of the survivors became carriers at the time ) but they still wouldn't free her.
She was a dorty woman!

Even so, Mary had very dirty habits that were shocking for her time. Wherever she lived, she lived in filth and squalor and did not clean up after herself. Her habits did not improve in quarantine, and they shocked employees who worked with her.
Yes by today's standards, but we have to remember that she was a product of her time before sanitation and hygiene techniques were properly understood by most people.

One reason Mary was locked up while other healthy carriers weren't must have been that health authorities didn't know what else to do. She was, after all, the first diagnosed healthy carrier in America. The flexible attitude for keeping healthy carriers out of the food industry was still in the future and by that time it was too late for Mary - she had blown one parole and they wouldn't trust her again.
Even without the typhoid you wouldn't want Mary Mallon cooking for you. By all accounts she was a slob with no sense of hygiene or cleanliness whatsoever.

Yikes! Coming into someone's workplace and telling them you think they're carrying typhoid in front of everyone? No wonder Mallon went all aggro! A more discreet, tactful approach might have made her more cooperative.
